name: Attachment-Based Family Therapy – Parenting (ABFT-P)
summary: A structured adaptation of ABFT focusing on strengthening parent-child attachment to improve adolescent emotional and behavioral health.
description: Attachment-Based Family Therapy for Parenting (ABFT-P) is an evidence-based, manualized family therapy model adapted from ABFT, designed to repair and strengthen the parent–child attachment bond. It aims to reduce adolescent distress, depression, and conflict by fostering open communication, rebuilding trust, and supporting parents in developing healthier relationships with their children. The therapy emphasizes emotion-focused discussions, parental attunement, and collaborative problem-solving to address relational ruptures and promote resilience.

contraindications: Families unwilling to engage in therapy
clinical_metadata.evidence_level: Strong; supported by randomized controlled trials.
clinical_metadata.research_support: ABFT and ABFT-P are well-researched interventions with demonstrated efficacy for adolescent depression and suicidality.

sections.text: ABFT-P enhances parent–child attachment by repairing relational ruptures and fostering emotional attunement. The therapy provides a safe space for adolescents to express distress, while guiding parents to respond with empathy and support. Strengthened attachment bonds reduce adolescent depression and suicidality and improve family functioning.

sections.preparation: Assessment of family dynamics, attachment ruptures, and adolescent emotional needs.
procedure: Initial sessions establish therapeutic alliance and clarify goals.
Individual meetings with parents focus on increasing attunement and reducing defensive responses.
Joint sessions facilitate emotional expression between parent and child.
Therapist guides parents in validating adolescent feelings and problem-solving collaboratively.
Ongoing monitoring and reinforcement of new relational patterns.

sections.pre_session: Review goals, emotional climate, and readiness for attachment-focused work.
sections.treatment_phase: Facilitate emotionally focused conversations, strengthen attachment bonds, repair relational ruptures.
sections.post_session: Summarize progress and assign home-based communication tasks.
sections.home_practice: Encourage families to practice open emotional communication and conflict resolution.

rare: Escalation of conflict if sessions are poorly managed

relative: Severe parental psychopathology interfering with participation
special_considerations: Requires motivation from both parents and adolescents

ideal_candidates: Adolescents with depression or suicidal ideation
Families experiencing relational disconnection or conflict
Parents motivated to rebuild attachment and communication
screening_required: Assessment for safety, readiness, and willingness to engage in therapy

practitioner: Licensed family therapists, psychologists, or social workers trained in ABFT

studies: Diamond, G.S. et al. (2002). Attachment-based family therapy for depressed adolescents: A treatment development study.
Diamond, G.S. et al. (2010). Attachment-based family therapy for adolescents with suicidal ideation: A randomized controlled trial.
sections.limitations: Most evidence focuses on depression and suicidality; broader applications need further study.

sections.insurance_coverage: Often covered under family therapy or psychotherapy benefits
sections.cost_effectiveness: Cost-effective compared to inpatient hospitalization for suicidal adolescents

sections.adolescents: Primary target group; therapy is designed for adolescent-parent dyads
sections.comorbidities: Adaptable for adolescents with comorbid anxiety or trauma

items: Focuses on repairing attachment ruptures as a pathway to reduce depression and suicidality.
Requires high therapist skill in managing intense family emotions.
Most effective when parents are motivated to change relational dynamics.

seo.title: Attachment-Based Family Therapy – Parenting (ABFT-P)
seo.description: Attachment-Based Family Therapy – Parenting (ABFT-P) is an evidence-based family therapy for adolescent depression, suicidality, and parent-child relational repair.
